update.description:
This is a continuation of the work to update inertia properties graphically, described in this [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md). Previously, pull request #1909 added a test for modifying mass and center-of-mass location over the `~/model/modify` topic. This pull request adds a test for modifying the diagonal moment of inertia terms. Modifying the off-diagonal terms (per issue #880) will require a bit more work.

The test uses a new world called `pendulum_axes.world`, created from an erb file. It has several boxes pinned at one end to the world, with a variety of link frame rotations and axis orientations. The test identifies the length of the pendulum and moment of inertia along the rotation axis and computes an expected frequency of oscillation (which is [derived in this ipython notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/raw/modify_moment_of_inertia/test/integration/physics_msgs_inertia.ipynb)).

Also, I made a small change to the `joint_friction_demo` world by adding physically accurate inertias to the links with prismatic joints. This doesn't affect the dynamics, since those links are prevented from rotating by the prismatic joint, but it makes the inertia visualization look nicer.

The test passes for ODE, bullet, and DART, but is disabled for simbody. The [jenkins-nvidia-dart4 build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/87/) is happy.
update.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

pull_request.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

pullrequest.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

content.raw:
[Entity::Reset](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/778edce9e6d3428ca20f091c734005cfdb89db85/gazebo/physics/Entity.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Entity.cc-602) resets the pose, and [Link::Reset](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/778edce9e6d3428ca20f091c734005cfdb89db85/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Link.cc-321) calls [Link::ResetPhysicsStates](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/778edce9e6d3428ca20f091c734005cfdb89db85/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Link.cc-331), which resets the velocity, acceleration, and force. These currently just affect the dynamic state, not any parameters like inertia, stiffness, friction, etc.

So I'll leave it out for now, though we could create an issue if we want to do that.
content.html:
Entity::Reset resets the pose, and Link::Reset calls Link::ResetPhysicsStates, which resets the velocity, acceleration, and force. These currently just affect the dynamic state, not any parameters like inertia, stiffness, friction, etc.

So I'll leave it out for now, though we could create an issue if we want to do that.

content.html: That's more of a general question and doesn't block this pull request. Approving.

content.raw:
I would like it to be clear; I consider this helpful, not noise. :)

I think this is the problematic part: "The moment of inertia *I* about the rotational axis at the center of mass is computed as:"

There are two geometrical aspects that are important for the computation, the location on the box, and the direction of the axis. What if I add that statement?

"Computing the moment of inertia requires specifying a location on the body and an axis direction. In the following equation, the moment of inertia *I* is computed at the center of mass along an axis parallel to the axis of rotation."

Is that better?
content.html:
I would like it to be clear; I consider this helpful, not noise. :)

I think this is the problematic part: "The moment of inertia I about the rotational axis at the center of mass is computed as:"

There are two geometrical aspects that are important for the computation, the location on the box, and the direction of the axis. What if I add that statement?

"Computing the moment of inertia requires specifying a location on the body and an axis direction. In the following equation, the moment of inertia I is computed at the center of mass along an axis parallel to the axis of rotation."

Is that better?

content.raw: Ohh I see, you start about the center of mass. I should have read more carefully. I guess I was confused by "about the rotational axis". Sorry for the noise.
content.html: Ohh I see, you start about the center of mass. I should have read more carefully. I guess I was confused by "about the rotational axis". Sorry for the noise.

pull_request.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

pullrequest.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

content.raw:
In the first section, I'm computing the moment of inertia with respect to the center of mass at the middle of the box. That image shows a coordinate frame at the end of the box, so I'm guessing that is the reference point. There is a [wikipedia page with lots of moments of inertia equations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_moments_of_inertia), and it shows equations for inertia of a rod with reference points at the center and at the end, and there is a factor of 4 difference between the two. That's my best guess.

The moment of inertia with respect to the center of a box is also on that page.
content.html:
In the first section, I'm computing the moment of inertia with respect to the center of mass at the middle of the box. That image shows a coordinate frame at the end of the box, so I'm guessing that is the reference point. There is a wikipedia page with lots of moments of inertia equations, and it shows equations for inertia of a rod with reference points at the center and at the end, and there is a factor of 4 difference between the two. That's my best guess.

The moment of inertia with respect to the center of a box is also on that page.

pull_request.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

pullrequest.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

content.raw:
Did you take the first equation from somewhere or did you derive it? Rusty physics here... 

I searched a bit and found [this](http://www.solitaryroad.com/c375/ole79.gif) image which suggests it should be `Ix = m/12 (4*(2L)^2 + (L/5)^2))`. But I have as much reason to believe it as to believe your notebook :)
content.html:
Did you take the first equation from somewhere or did you derive it? Rusty physics here...

I searched a bit and found this image which suggests it should be Ix = m/12 (4*(2L)^2 + (L/5)^2)). But I have as much reason to believe it as to believe your notebook :)
